main_text:
The Lead-up to the Debate
2. The Lead-up to the Debate

Since about 1700 theories about the nature and structure of the
Universe were derived from Newtonian theory, most especially his
theory of gravitation, which was used to account for the behavior of
heavenly bodies and their systems. Newton’s theory hypothesized
a force—gravitation—acting upon material bodies, free to
move over time within the passive, inert ‘container’ of
three-dimensional space. Bodies, paths, and space itself exemplified
the classical geometry of Euclid. All these features changed with the
publication of Einstein’s General Theory of Relativity,
1915–17.
entry_title: Cosmology: Methodological Debates in the 1930s and 1940s
